comments.commentBody: Nice piece that raises good questions. KJ, this is one of those many family decisions where you know the best decision for your family.  I have a tweener from China, and especially given the doubts a number of Chinese adults we know have expressed about her official finding story, I would have searched.  I did a lot of initial info-gathering when she was young in preparation for the day.  The day not only has not come, but as she gets older, she emphatically made her opposition to searching very clear.  I've tried to offer a balanced view of the issues, and she articulately tells me why her dad and I are wrong.  I too believe there are many decisions that are the parent's to make and cannot be left to a child.  She has had no choice but to have a flu shot every year, attend the schools we've selected for her, see the orthodontist, do her homework, and get to bed on time.  She's made it clear for a few years now that searching would be against her will. She can clearly articulate all that to other adults. I'm perfectly willing to facilitate and fund a search if she decides otherwise, but right now, we're not going there.

We should have used grants/managed service agreements, not loan guarantees. We should have spent twice as much. The idea that Solyndra could have survived in a market dominated by existing companies that control every one of Porter's forces. We should have issued RFPs and awarded them to the best (not lowest) bids.

The government sector adds to the economy by spending. All private sector transactions net to zero. It is a simple matter that is refused based upon a moral/theological bias against common will being used to advance common well being.

It is saddening.

It is the tidal waves of the ocean, that best describes the fickled results of the polling data surrounding the Republican presidential campaign. New names swept in, only to be swept out, indiscriminately.

It does look like a weak field of presidential candidates.

The newest surge has been Newt Gingrich. At best, a career politician that never gave up or went away; composed of never ending fodder for the Obama Machine, if he were to become the nominee. A Gingrich nomination would be a death-knell to the spirit of the tea party movement and their goal to remove entrenched career politicians.

The revolving door in Washington, composed of rejected politicians (defeated in re-election, or forced out by unethical actions) becoming lobbyist, now virtually a shadow government on K-Street...would be the ultimate...for a Gingrich return to Washington as our new president.

It is fundamentally immoral and wrong.

The tidal waves of rational discourse will sweep Gingrich out with the likes of Perry and Cain. Sadly the anchor that Republicans and Independents are looking for is being glaringly ignored by those that are defending the Perry, Cain, and the Gingrich group...Gov. Romney, is not a favorite with the Limbaugh-Fox News consortium of whats good for America.

The Gingrich surge while helped by debate performance (no great passionate fire in the belly to be seen, but the usual diatribe of savvy political talk) must be acknowledged, to be the affect of almost daily appearances on Fox News Hannity TV, and the Hannity radio talk show.

Fair and balanced, the Fox News mantra, is a joke; while O'Reilly is constantly critisizing his competition for biases, they are overwhelmingly guilty of what they preach. Their positive Gingrich exposures versus the lack of Romney apperances and nuanced Romney slights are evident.

Despite it all, the achor is not much moved by the waves of political machinations...Romney holding steady, waiting to serve his country.
I remember during the 1960 campaign Eisenhower's response when a reporter  queried him about what NIxon had done as Vice President. Eisenhower replied that, given a week, he might think of something.
Isn't a brain freeze an ice cream headache?

Football has been a corrupting influence at Penn State for decades, and the corruption extends to the town of State College PA and the police and civil authorities, as well as state media outlets.  No one wanted to jeopardize the football program and the money and fame it brought to the university.  No one wanted to upset JoePa.  Joe Paterno and the university were given a pass by all who investigated (not) this mess.  Of course there should be payouts to the victims.  Paterno et al thought they were protecting the program and the university.  But look where their moral blindness and cowardice led them.

I saw the debate online, in a three-part replay at http://www.2012presidentialelectionnews.com/2012-debate-schedule/2011-20... , because CNBC didn't live-stream it. It's possible the replay, on my little laptop, was slightly slowed. However, it's possible it was not. That being said, I detected a slight slurring of Perry's words, distinct from his so-called 'Southern drawl'. Or, in other words, it appeared to me that he'd 'had a couple' right before the debate - maybe to relax?

I agree with other posters - unfortunately, he seems a talking head - doing the bidding of his campaign contributors. While I'm certain he'd be great company at a bar stool, and could charmingly laugh away his gaffes, without the real substance behind the words, the talking head (albeit charming and, in my opinion, tipsy) revealed himself as the emperor with no clothes.

For all the talk about President Obama and the teleprompter I would point out that:
1. He is not the first President to use one
2. The President has a speech impediment- he stutters and anyone who stutters know that it helps when you have the words in front of you to read for fluency. I have seen him in interviews - he thinks carefully before he answers (it is not that his answers are ignorant) but he takes extra time because of the stuttering.

I felt sorry for Perry and think the media as usual is simply going overboard (and I don't even like the guy)
He forgot because he couldn't remember what someone told him to say. Problem is nobody now believes he's really into these positions.

This man is just another of our wonderful governors that is a presidential wannabe. Like the one before him, who happened to have a father who made it happen with money and power, this one is stupid. He proves it over and over here in Texas. Ask anybody involved in public Education here in Texas. Ash anyone who counts on any kind of social program. Ask anyone who counts on Social Security and knows that it isn't a Ponzi scheme. Ask anyone who has a functioning brain. The saddest part about all of this is that he may very well get the GOP nomination and maybe even get elected. If so, we 99r's are all in trouble.
Don't be surprised that these scandals can be covered for almost 20 years. This is always a country where money rules.

I hope this is a wake up call for the entire country. There are things more important than football, money and power. These children have been betrayed twice....by their abuser Sandusky, and by those who failed to protect them. Unbelievable.

I agree completely with #3.  It's not the football program though, it's the people who run it that need to be thrown out.  The board did the right thing in immediately canning the president and other perps.

In many states, you have to sue the state in special courts of claims and you're not entitled to a jury trial. In addition, there are often limits on the amount of damages which can be collected against the state. If that's the case in Pennsylvania, then the potential liability of the university and its employees could be considerably reduced.

Think these guys where investigated by the police and the case was closed. Paterno did notify the College President and should have go to the police but notice the cops got paid to close the matter.  All this talk about child molestation yet Senator Brown announced he was raped as a child but refuses to expose the rapist name. Brown's rapist has been raping kids for over twenty years thanks to the setting Senator staying silent. How many kids could have been saved if Brown spoke up?  Cain sexually harass women and people cheer and support him.  Who will protect the children when those who rape them are the one's people hold up as leaders. As the President said Penn State should care more for the children raped then defending a person involved and the College that allowed it to continue for such a long time.  Senator Brown will get re elect and not give a thought about the children his rapist are raping even today.

It's really long past time to go nuclear on anyone, any institution, any politician involved in this kind of evil.  Our society has degraded to such a level that we too often look past despicable behavior.  Why is Elliot Spitzer not in jail?  Why are not every Catholic priest, bishop, etc not serving hard time for their egregious transgressions?  Why is Bill Clinton lauded as some kind of demigod?  This is pure disgrace.

I was a Penn State and "Joe Pa" fan for many years and even though they weren't a Stanford in graduation rates or perennial champions I respected that they were near the top both on the field and in the classroom for a very long time, But after this fiasco I think to save the taxpayer some of the cost for THEIR legal fees and the legal civil judgments that will probably be in the hundreds of millions that they should pay for this with money that they already have in the till including ALL football money, shut down the place and sell all the real estate and then start over and start small.

There are two words to describe the entire Penn State affair: obnoxious and disgusting. I am not at all surprised that these moronic students went nuts, as these kids have a role model JoePa. Well the apple does not fall far from  the tree. Those kids' moral compass is as deplorable as their head coach's and the entire university's top management. This is supposed to be an university that many others try to emulate ? No wonder, America is falling behind !!! These college kids need to understand that football is not what is going to  help this country compete globally. Get a real life and stop worshipping irrelevant stuff

The only action Paterno and his ilk will understand is hitting at their billions.  Let us hope some good lawyers start the process as soon as possible.  All the kids who were victimized should be compensated and all the fat cats who looked the other way should be bankrupted.

Penn St does supervise "children" during the summers when each Penn St  sports team has on campus camps for children. In some cases these children stay over night.  So contrary to what's suggested in the article the fact that children are supervised  may open the door to these actions.

"I'd shut down the entire football program immediately."

@3,

Yes, that's what we should do. Punish all of the football player kids who had absolutely nothing to do with this.

Children pay Penn State to attend these camps that are run by PennState employees th
erefore Penn State is an institution that supervises children.

The penalties for not reporting and not stopping the crime; then creating an elaborate cover up, along with the moral turpitude in allowing the monster Sandusky continued access to Penn State should be so strong that they discourage such deceptions in the future. The penalty for not reporting this ongoing crime must exceed the benefits of the cover-up. I hope that the lawyers for the victims find a way to drive a bulldozer through whatever legal protections the university's status allows. The crime is base enough.  The penalty for deception must send a message that the protection of children is paramount.
are the administrators of all institutions who are trusted to protect the safety of all within it's domain now checking themselves?

Why, why, why is Mr. Sandusky out on $100,000 unsecured bail? With forty counts of sexual assault, at least some of which (perhaps all) are felony charge and the possibility of spending the rest of his life in jail (as a child rapist at that) he is the classic flight risk and danger to the community. What in the world was the basis for Judge Dutchcot's decision to release this man essentially on his own recognizance?
